qa_pairs.question: How do you activate the stroke code?
qa_pairs.answer: Activate stroke code via 33333. If stroke is suspected and if last known well less than 12 hours, activate stroke code via 33333.

qa_pairs.question: What is the door-to-ED MD evaluation time target for stroke patients?
What is the door-to-stroke team assessment time target?
What is the door-to-CT performed time target?
What is the door-to-IV tPA administration time target?
What contact numbers are used for acute stroke team notification?
qa_pairs.answer: Call AMAC to activate acute stroke code or call stroke code operator via 33333. For specific services: Neurosurgery Consult Beeper 2009; Neuroradiology x44261 (Mon-Fri 8am-11pm, Sat & Sun 8am-5pm), off hours page radiology resident at Beeper 1490

qa_pairs.question: What is the time window for IV tPA eligibility?
qa_pairs.answer: Onset of acute stroke symptoms within 3 hours. Between 3 and 4.5 hours from symptom onset, selected patients may be eligible for treatment with IV alteplase, at the discretion of the treating vascular neurologist.

qa_pairs.question: What blood pressure parameters contraindicate IV tPA?
qa_pairs.answer: Systolic BP > 185 and Diastolic BP > 110 despite treatment

qa_pairs.question: What is the tPA dosing regimen?
qa_pairs.answer: 0.9 mg/kg (maximum of 90 mg) tPA (alteplase, Activase) infused over 60 minutes with 10% of the total dose administered as an initial intravenous bolus over 1 minute
qa_pairs.source_section: Management of the IV tPA-eligible Patient

qa_pairs.question: What is the pharmacy hotline number for tPA preparation?
qa_pairs.answer: x7-8789 - Call the ED pharmacist or the pharmacy tPA hotline at x7-8789 for all cases requiring tPA preparation, regardless of patient location or time of day

qa_pairs.question: What are the vital sign monitoring requirements during tPA infusion?
qa_pairs.answer: Every 15 minutes x 2 hours (includes the hour of IV tPA administration), Then every 30 minutes x 6 hours, Then every 60 minutes x 16 hours
qa_pairs.source_section: Management of the IV tPA-eligible Patient

qa_pairs.question: What blood pressure targets should be maintained during tPA infusion?
qa_pairs.answer: Maintain blood pressure at or below systolic blood pressure 180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure 105 mm Hg. If systolic >185 or diastolic >110, give Labetalol 10-20 mg IV over 1-2 minutes (may repeat x1) OR Nicardipine 5 mg/hr IV infusion

qa_pairs.question: What should you do if angioedema is suspected during tPA?
qa_pairs.answer: Alert the physician for early discontinuation of the tPA infusion. Administer Benadryl 50 mg IV and Famotidine 20 mg IV. If tongue continues to enlarge, give Solumedrol 80-100 mg IV. If further enlargement, give epinephrine 0.1% 0.3 mL SC or 0.5 mL via nebulizer and call ENT, anesthesiology or other appropriate in-house service STAT.
qa_pairs.source_section: Assessment for and Management of Angioedema

qa_pairs.question: What are the contraindications for IV tPA related to recent procedures?
qa_pairs.answer: Intracranial or spinal surgery, or serious head trauma within the last 3 months; Gastrointestinal Hemorrhage within the last 21 days

qa_pairs.question: For patients NOT eligible for IV tPA, when should antihypertensive agents be avoided?
qa_pairs.answer: Antihypertensive agents should be avoided unless the Systolic BP is > 220 mm Hg or the MAP is > 100 mm Hg or treatment of co-morbid end-organ involvement, such as aortic dissection, AMI, pulmonary edema, or hypertensive encephalopathy, is needed
qa_pairs.source_section: Management of Patients NOT Eligible for IV tPA
